question_text: A 60-year-old woman is evaluated after a leukocyte count of 55,000/µL (55 × 109/L) was found incidentally on a routine complete blood count.Peripheral blood smear is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) (Option D). CML is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder characterized by translocation of the long arm of chromosomes 9 and 22 [t(9;22), Philadelphia chromosome] leading to a BCR::ABL fusion gene. This gene codes for an abnormal activated tyrosine kinase that promotes dysregulated cell proliferation. In CML, peripheral blood neutrophilia along with circulating immature myeloid forms, such as myelocytes and metamyelocytes, are seen. This peripheral blood smear shows myelocytes (red arrows), band forms (white arrows), and mature polymorphonuclear neutrophils (green arrows). At diagnosis, patients with CML can be asymptomatic, with elevated neutrophil counts found on routine laboratory studies, or they can have symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, abdominal fullness (secondary to splenomegaly), and bleeding.
